author: jakepospischil
content:
My understanding (correct me if I'm wrong) is that the existing BLS withdrawal credentials also can't be used to initiate validator exits; this can only be done by the validator pubkey (https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/beacon-chain.md#voluntary-exits). So eth1 withdrawal creds would be no different in this regard, right?

Either way, this should not be an issue for Rocket Pool specifically. To elaborate on <@!405158743920345128>' comment above, user stakes in RP are tokenized as rETH, which has a dynamic exchange rate for ETH based on total network value (this is reported by oracle nodes and includes eth2 validator balances). rETH can be burned for ETH at the current exchange rate, subject to liquidity.

Node operators (who hold the validator pubkeys) are disincentivised from holding validator balances hostage as they are bonded by fronting half of the deposit themselves. If they do so anyway, then they can limit ETH liquidity within RP. However, since user stakes are tokenized, users can easily exit their position on the open market at a marginal discount if this happens. The possibility of *some* illiquidity is basically implied as part of the risk for RP stakers, and is something we're comfortable with.

I can't speak for other staking pools, but I imagine the pattern of tokenizing stakes is/will be fairly common and it seems like this is not a big issue for anyone doing so.
